patterns: I don't feel that I will amount to anything
School often makes me feel worthless and I don't feel that I can follow my dreams because everything is so academically revolved around.
Why am I never good enough?
My test scores are so bad
responses: Your grades do not define you. You're more intelligent than you think. Take it easy on yourself and pace your work. Of course, you can't just fool around, but you can't exert yourself to the point of exhaustion either. It is all about you. You need to focus on yourself.
What do you think is causing this?
Take a deep breath and gather your thoughts. Go take a walk if possible. Stay hydrated
Give yourself a break. Go easy on yourself.
I am sorry to hear that. What is the reason behind this?

patterns: I'm lost, tired, and burned out from school. I have a lot to do and their deadlines are getting near.
Burned out from school, research, and mcat.
I haven’t gotten a break from school and work and I think it’s caused me to burn out.
I have constant cycles of burn out no matter what I do.
Why do I burn out so easily?
How do I deal with burn out?
responses: Burnout is a repetitive motion injury. Doing the same thing over and over at a level of stress that eventually causes harm. The only solution is to not repeat that motion over and over, so finding out exactly what is causing the burnout is the first step. Is it a never-ending pile of homework or due dates at work that you just can't seem to get out of? Is it long hours day after day with no time to relax? Once you identify the biggest reason for your burnout, start thinking about how you can change the motion.

You are not lazy. A struggle with laziness is really just the result of a lack of clarity on your priorities. That's all it is. When you have this sorted, everything else falls into place. Make clear your highest priorities and link them clearly to the necessary daily actions, so that you can see that there is no progress unless you do what you need to do today.

Frustration can be hard to put into words – it’s a complicated mix of anger, disappointment, and annoyance. Start by taking a deep breath. Focusing on your breath and breathing deeply from your diaphragm can help reduce negative feelings and ease any tension you may have in your body.

patterns: I've struggled with procrastination my whole life
responses: Your brain adapts to, and then perpetuates, the habits to which it is constantly exposed. That fact doesn't work in your favor right now, but you can change that. Try to structure your time and figure out why you procrasinate. Learn to tolerate or even enjoy putting time and effort into your work. More than that, incentivize your productvitity. You are your own RPG hero.

responses: So first I would suggest you to give yourself a break. Thinking more and more about the problem definitely does not help in solving it. You'll just end up overwhelming yourself.

responses: Next, I would suggest you to practice meditation. Meditation can produce a deep state of relaxation and a tranquil mind.

responses: Your welcome. Remember: Always focus on what's within your control. When you find yourself worrying, take a minute to examine the things you have control over. You can't prevent a storm from coming but you can prepare for it. You can't control how someone else behaves, but you can control how you react. Recognize that sometimes, all you can control is your effort and your attitude. When you put your energy into the things you can control, you'll be much more effective.
